726231f-a.text:
Broadway (police thereon), north from Queens Boulevard, showing at the left on the N.W. corner the Heeg Hotel erected by John Heeg in 1891. This structure was partially demolished in October 1930.
Portions of it, however, still remain.
March 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

727704f-a.text:
Queens Boulevard, north side, west of Broadway to Van Loon Street. Eugene L. Armbruster states that the building in the foreground was the original Baptist Church of Elmhurst and that it was erected in 1809. This structure originally stood on the damaica Road, south side, east of Horse Brook Road, and was moved to Grand Street in 1857 and remodeled (opposite Town Hallf) and from the last
location was moved to the present site.
January 1923.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

726756f-a.folder: Grand Avenue & Queens Boulevard, Queens, NY

727709f-a.text:
Queens Boulevard at the S.E. corner of Grand Avenue, showing the corner house. It was erected about 1716 by Jonathan Fish who kept a tavern. Hie died in 1723. His son Samuel conducted it until he died 1767. Abraham Rapelye operated it during the Revolutionary War. At this time it was also the headquarters of the Loyalists. After the war it was called the Union Hotel. On May 3, 1817 it was purchased by the town for the Presbyterian Parsonage for the Rev. Wm. Boardman and used as such until 1822 when the 3rd parsonage was erected. Rev. Boardman died 1818 and was succeeded by the Rev. John Goldsmith D.D. The house was sold in 1822 and was used first as a store and then for many years as a residence. It stood vacant for years and was finally taken down. This site was originally occupied by the house of Ralph Hunt. Peter Duryea
was the owner in 1852.
Nugene L. Armbruster Collectionn
727709f-a.folder: Queens Boulevard & Grand Avenue, Queens, NY
